awd_titl_txt: An Ecosystem for Success in Engineering and Computer Science in Rio South Texas
awd_abstract_narration: This project is being supported under a special funding focus for STEP, "Graduate 10K+," an activity of the National Science Foundation, supported in part by donations from the Intel Foundation and the GE Foundation, to stimulate comprehensive action at universities and colleges to help increase the annual number of new B.S. graduates in engineering and computer science by 10,000 over the next decade. In particular, this project is addressing preparation, retention and graduation of engineering and computer-science students at the University of Texas - Pan American, primarily through four activities: 1) a STEM-focused concurrent-enrollment program for area high-school students, 2) a summer bridge program for entering UTPA first-year students, emphasizing mathematics preparation, 3) supplemental instruction in gatekeeper courses for STEM majors, and 4) augmented peer mentoring and tutoring.  The intellectual merit of the project lies in its multifaceted approach that is leveraging best practices from the STEM educational literature, and also is building on considerable prior efforts and strong partnerships with area schools and with South Texas College, a two-year institution.  Beyond the projected increases in engineering and computer-science graduates, broader impacts include strengthening the workforce for an emerging hub in advanced manufacturing in Rio South Texas, as well as support for greater educational and economic achievement in a high-needs region. The project is also providing a model of national interest for greater success and degree attainment by Hispanic students in STEM.

inst.inst_name: The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY

por.por_cntn:
Activity 1: Over 100 HS students received between 6 and 12 college credit hours towards their chosen college STEM degrees.  The supportive community provided by the UPREP program for them was a critical element in their success.  For many this was their first college experience and the on-campus residential dorm experience, peers from the TexPREP program and UG STEM mentors and tutors helped to ensure success and encourage future enrollment in UG STEM programs.

During the last four years of UPREP, the TexPREP program was expanded to the Brownsville campus.  With the same enthusiasm for students getting college credit in their 5th year of the program, we saw parental enthusiasm and significant growth of the new program.  Each year we added an additional year of curriculum in Brownsville through the 4th year which is still in operation at a peak enrollment of about 160 students. Brownsville students participating in UPREP was not possible due to COVID-19. 

Activity 2: Students with unsuccessful high school experiences in advanced mathematics courses, Pre-Calculus or Calculus, can be advanced at a significantly faster pace than the traditional College Algebra - Precalculus sequence. We have designed a 4-credit course that covers content from both our College Algebra and Pre-Calculus course. In 4 years, 90 students successfully transitioned to placement into Calculus 1 three-credits earlier than usual, and at a higher rate than in the traditional College Algebra and Pre-Calculus path. These students were as successful in Calculus 1 as the general population. The course was designed as an emporium style class.  For cohorts 1-2, we used the ALEKS (http://www.aleks.com ) software; however, for cohort 3-5 we designed a WebWork template for the course. An important broader impact of our project has been repackaging the WebWork template for our course as Pre-Calculus template for local high schools. Twenty regional high schools in the seven surrounding counties of South Texas were using this template in their courses.

 "image1"

Our co-PI, Dr. Virgil Pierce, recommended to use the free online textbook and  http://www.opentextbookstore.com/precalc/ and WebWork (https://webwork.utrgv.edu/) to increase the sustainability of the project.

Activity 2 was not implemented after summer 2018 because Dr. Pierce moved away from UTRGV to a new job.

Activities 3 and 4: During 2014-2022, work was performed involving a total of 2805 lower-level students in the College of Engineering and Computer Science at UTRGV in several gatekeeper courses including Statics, Dynamics, Electrical and Electronic Systems, Chemistry for Engineers, Digital Systems Eng. I, Engineering Computer Science I, Calculus I, Engineering Statistics, Engineering Analysis I.

 

The following materials and tools were developed and implemented for the Statics course and shared with instructors of other gatekeeper courses at UTRGV and also during a workshop for 28 community college instructors from TSTC and STC in May of 2018. The workshop consisted of Introduction how people learn?; Review of pre-requisite material in gatekeeper courses.; Kahoot electronic response; Pretest: topics, questions; Identifying at-risk students; Mentoring and lessons learned; Challenge-based instruction (CBI) and challenges. Involved courses in the community college were the following: Statics, Electrical Circuits, Calculus I, College Algebra, Chemistry I, Biology I, Physics I, Data and Voice Communication and Convergent Technology.  A total of 448 students (42% females) participated in the activities in those courses, and even though 41% were identified as at-risk at the beginning of the semester, 70.1% of all the students passed the courses.

Interventions yielded some significant improvements in passing rates and increased in the number of A and B grades. In Statics, taught by different instructors from 2006 and 2013 with passing rates around 60% increased to 68% in recent semester (spring 2019), and the percentage of A and B grades increased from ~33% to as much as 50%.

Activities 4: During the TexPREP program, NSF-STEP supported faculty and UG students made presentations to students and their families about STEM career opportunities and demands. Based on the NSF STEP grant and the ongoing investment of UTRGV College administration, the UTRGV TexPREP program was expanded to the Brownsville campus. Beside the academic related interventions, they also motivated students by presenting career opportunities available (e.g., internships and full-time jobs) in the courses mentioned above.

Early identification of at-risk students led to interventions with supplementary instruction activities, such as peer led mentoring sessions, challenges, and online assessments.

Activity 5.  We were able to recruit 17 students transferring from community college to the COEC through the bridge to engineering program; they got a scholarship that consisted of tuition for two sophomore courses at UTRGV preferably in the first semester after transferring, with the purpose of incentivize them to be successful at UTRGV. Our intention was to recruit many more students during the 2021-2022 period, but of 212 transfer students, 10 applied of the program and 8 were admitted because of economic need and academic performance requirements.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Horacio Vasquez

Image
  • Bridge to Calculus - Results
    Dr Pierce
    Public Domain
    Horacio Vasquez
    Bridge to Calculus
